content.content: Inherently the biggest problem on the vault compensation report wasn’t doing 1 scenario but setting up to do a whole bunch of different ones.   I was already looking at ETH DAI valuations to present one but gave up after a short time. I think if there is some focus to discussion it will be to talk about the class of auctions we consider defective (1), and then (2) to decide what we think is a reasonable collateral return scenario under the market conditions where liquidation happened.   My arbitrary (based on my business experience) split the difference between what someone could expect or want vs. what I could expect or want is in the right ballpark (10-12% collateral return) and this is what we saw as a rough average when additional keepers came on line. So unless someone has a really strong arguement for more (perhaps an emotional compensation, since this was stressful for everyone), or less (because really under these circumstance expecting ANY collateral return is a pretty high expectation) landing right in the middle (give or take a few percent) honestly seems reasonable.    Then the issue becomes the auction criterion selection process, but honestly even if one selects all with a collateral deficiency relative to the nominal value chosen the amount doesn’t more than double from left (0-bid) to right (ALL with a collateral deficit relative to chosen nominal). The value of ETH in DAI - that is a whole different can of worms.

content.content: If this next poll is not to contradict the previous then it should ask the question of how to best achieve the benefits/objectives voted for already. Below are the  “Arguments for compensation” as presented to voters in the previous poll for reference: The protocol performed in a sub-optimal manner. Users (i.e. vault holders) were injured. It is in the interest of Maker holders to try to make their users happy. The purpose of the MKR token is to insure against precisely this kind of failure. No compensation may represent a distortion of symmetry and reciprocity i.e. the impression that we’re marketing the product and receiving the reward for growth of the platform, but leaving ecosystem/development risk entirely to the user. This could negatively impact reputation and future mass adoption. Avoid bad press and acrimonious gestures. https://vote.makerdao.com/polling-proposal/qmwfvvguaf8rz8xwgv2cqnzzt9t5h6epzh17qmk2ue99y4 Compensation done “down the middle” as suggested or any other fraction may appear reasonable, but will likely not achieve these objectives and in that sense be fruitless since you would have spent a great deal of DAI and still sit with the reputational damage, bad press, injured vault holders, negative impact on mass adoption etc. You would not have achieved the benefits voted for in the first poll. Further defending a “reasonable” percentage in front of the press, injured users and potential legal proceedings could be difficult and more so being represented by a collective. The cleanest, quickest route ending the matter and focusing on the future could prove an investment especially considering you are not dealing with a single party you can shake hands with - all you have are your actions signalling intent and impacting brand and reputation. For all these audiences you likely would have to be seen to have “done all you could” acting in the interest of users and that’s likely what will count in articles written on this issue. Considering the interest in the matter and competition in the space this could be defining for Maker. Having said this presenting too many choices could be misleading and I propose we rather focus on fewer options framing the poll in a way that extends directly to desired outcomes. Otherwise you could be caught in a classic “decision by committee” trap diluting the question at hand to averages and missing the outcomes altogether. A voter may think 12% is reasonable, but want the outcomes 24% would likely bring if the question was framed differently. This is not a strange concept - giving customers more than is reasonable is basically Amazon’s ethos. The framing of the poll should focus on outcomes and provide limited options.

content.content: Sandhaai:  Compensation done “down the middle” as suggested or any other fraction may appear reasonable, but will likely not achieve these objectives and in that sense be fruitless since you would have spent a great deal of DAI and still sit with the reputational damage, bad press, injured vault holders, negative impact on mass adoption etc.   No amount of compensation is going to make those things go away, frankly. That gives us the best idea of what Vault Holders could have expected had there been enough (but not copious amounts) of keeper liquidity. I’d actually like to split the difference between 0% and 11%, and return 5.5%. I just want to be clear they should not be considered the canonical source of truth on what the responsibilities of MKR Token Holders are, or what their reasons for voting in favor would be.  Regarding what the poll looks like, we’ll do our best to structure it to capture as much signal as possible, as efficiently as possible. We’ll also try to make sure it’s objective as possible. I’m sure full compensation of 24% will be on the poll. I’m also fairly sure that 0% compensation will be on the poll, given that we now have more information regarding auction effectiveness and the cost of compensation than we did previously, and that this new information may have caused people to change their minds. Probably we’ll see a few options between those extremes too.

content.content: Your interpretation of symmetry is fairly sketchy, in my view, for several reasons:  MKR Token Holders already suffered the downside from this in the form of FLOP auctions. Recapitalising the system is the only thing MKR Token Holders are obligated to pay for (by design). It’s also worth mentioning that UI’s in some cases do sell services that benefit from network growth (increased customer base.) I believe DeFi Saver charges for one or more of their services, though I forget which. You could also argue that the Ethereum network benefits from the DeFi projects built on top of it.  It may be beneficial for MKR Token Holders to pay some amount of compensation for Vault Holders in this situation, but they certainly aren’t obligated to do so. I appreciate you are all frustrated, but I’m doing as much as possible to approach this from a position of objectivity and trying to figure out how much compensation MKR Token Holders are actually responsible for rather than giving a knee-jerk response.      uvizhe:  I’d say that the split is between ~24.67% (what vault owners expected) and 10-12% (what should be expected).   Why? Are MKR Token Holders responsible for the expectations of Vault Holders? 24.67% is the theoretical maximum in a system that relies on auctions, it’s not a reasonable assumption to receive that much back. A reasonable assumption is based on historical return in the case of liquidations (17.7%), a reasonable assumption given what was possibly a once or twice in a lifetime event is 11%. Splitting the difference between the reasonable assumption given the situation and what was actually received seems like the fairest outcome to me given that the unprecedented market situation was made worse by insufficiently defensive auction parameters (the thing that MKR Token Holders are actually responsible for).  Like if anyone can provide a solid argument as to why MKR Token Holders are responsible for compensating the full amount given their role in Black Thursday, please share it. Note that I’m talking about responsibility, not what may or may not make sense given PR issues.

content.content: Thank you for posting that article @Sandhaai I am going to add a main comment.   I still consider myself relatively new here, but I consider as probably the HIGHEST priority of Maker to deal with suring up the auction/liquidation system.   I have refrained from posting my DSR-L Liquidation back stop mechanism simply because some of the recommendations in my liquidation report are base requirements for the DSR-L.  We absolutely need to re-kick auctions if they don’t meet some minimum bid requirements not just in terms of price but also of number of participants. We need to stagger lot sizes in auctions.   This is key to gaining a better scientific view of auction processes. Change how the system operates if the auction price being offered or will fetch is significantly lower than the OSM.  (disjointed OSM to market) I think a review of the auction process itself with a goal of not just doing the least to sure up the system now is important but looking to the future to make a more efficient auction system which is easy to access for the most players.  Literally with the above I’d like to finally just nail down what I consider to be one of the biggest flaws in the Maker system, the liquidation process.   There are others to be sure but this one just stands out at me, probably because of how closely I have looked at the system. Maker community needs to take this seriously and really put some effort into driving this nail down. I am not going to MIPify my DSR-L proposal but at some point I am going to post it for consideration and leave it be.   What I have not done yet is to take the proposal and run it through a monte carlo simulation.   Honestly what I want to do is to just run the data from Black Thursday into it but I have not had the time, yet and the community seems to have its hands full of all kinds of other issues.   One other issue that cropped up from my work is this idea of the OSM and auction market bid/deal prices being disjointed.   This is a condition that needs to raise a flag operationally and ideally throttle or halt processes until the flag condition goes away.   To be sure I have looked at the risk scenarios here with the suggestions I will be making and frankly they are not worse than the ones we have in the system right now. Expect a post at least on the DSR-L at some point in the future.   I think there are so many steps in this process and so much discussion that literally nothing will happen for at least a year and I don’t think the DeFI space can wait.   We really need to fast track some solid approaches that can be overridden or managed manually by governance in a pinch.   12hrs may seem like a long time to wait to do something but if we design the system to be conservative and overly safe as we can by alleviating run-away conditions we already know about (OSM attack is one, black swan is another) we can then provide a solid and well defined operational backstop to the entire DeFi space that will provide a greater confidence to all participants during tail risk type events. The real problem here is everyone wants to run headlong into taking peoples capital and providing a service because it is ‘cool’ or ‘necessary’.  If at least one DeFI project doesn’t stand up and say, “we will go a little slower and more carefully for the sake of the entire DeFI space”, I have serious concerns during another Market crash ALL of DeFI will crash and burn, and everyone will throw up their hands and say “oh well, we did our best” and then hope we can rebuild. Heck with rebuilding after the DeFI a-bomb, lets just try to do the best we can to avoid the financial nuke we are building from laying waste to a massively growing but fragile space.
